page.title: 15SILAGE MAKING - BOFARNEL
page.content: Silage making is an important operation for the farm. It begins in early spring with fertilising the grass and rolling it to ensure that surface stones do not damage the machinery. Cutting normally starts in early May followed 24 hours later by a forage harvester which picks up the grass chops it and blows it into trails which are taken back to the silage clamp and ensiled. If the weather is unsettled an acid additive is used to ensure a good fermentation in the clamp. The essence of good silage-making is cutting grass at the optimum growth stage, speed of ensiling, a good sealing, stopping the rain and air coming in, keeping contamination out of the grass and use of acid additive if weather conditions are uncertain.
